Show Me No thanks, close See our Privacy Notice An Edinburgh pub has shared the moment that their staff headed to a busy theatre to flyer for their business through 'singing and dancing' as Hamilton fans made their way out of the opening night of the tour.
Staff from Dropkick Murphy's headed to Festival Theatre on Wednesday evening, February 28, in freezing weather, to advertise for their popular boozer. Staff from the venue took to the streets with speakers, flyers and posters to 'embrace and celebrate' the award-winning musical making its Edinburgh debut.
Footage uploaded on social media by staff at the pub shows hundreds of Hamilton fans leaving the sold out venue and being welcomed by Dropkick Murphy's staff carrying on the performance. Staff were out in full swing with their microphones to sing some of the hit songs from the musical with some fans dancing along.

One of the owners at Dropkicks, Donal Hurrell, is hoping that they will be able to continue celebrating the hit musical being in the Scottish capital for the duration of the two month run.
Speaking to Edinburgh Live, he said: "“We were really excited to see Hamilton coming to Edinburgh and to embrace and celebrate this, we organised some PR staff to flyer outside but I also got my son Tommy Hurrell (who busks around the city & is a huge fan of the show), to sing Hamilton songs with the PR staff as well.
"Despite the horrible weather it was great fun to see people leaving the theatre, buzzing from the Hamilton performance and even singing along with our buskers. Lots of the audience then went to Dropkicks to continue their night which was great and we hope to see this over the two month run.
"We also held a karaoke competition to mark Hamilton's opening night, where we gave away two tickets to the show. We were blown away by the response and the number of fans that entered, but also on the level of the singing quality.
"Have to say that Napier Musical Theatre (one of our sponsored societies) were just amazing and helped create a great show along with students from all other universities".

Fiona Gibson CEO of Capital Theatres who runs the Festival Theatre previously said: “We’re utterly thrilled to be hosting the Scottish Premiere of Hamilton at the Festival Theatre. It’s even more significant that Alexander Hamilton was of Scottish descent, so in many ways the story is coming home.

"To have this iconic show which has delighted audiences round the world here at the Festival Theatre and in Edinburgh where Lin-Manuel Miranda once busked at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is really special."
